message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a corneal abrasion, which can be confirmed with a fluorescein examination. Ocular ultrasonography, gonioscopy, and CT scan of the orbit are not necessary for diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are suggestive of corneal abrasion or ulcer, which can be detected using fluorescein examination. Ocular ultrasonography, gonioscopy, and CT scan of the orbit are less relevant in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of a corneal abrasion, most likely caused by his contact lenses. Fluorescein examination is the most appropriate and common method to diagnose corneal abrasions. Ocular ultrasonography, gonioscopy, and CT scan of the orbit are not necessary for this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The immediate pain and discomfort, persistence of foreign body sensation, and relief of pain with topical anesthetic suggest the presence of a corneal abrasion. Fluorescein examination will help confirm the diagnosis by showing staining of the affected area. The other options are not necessary for the diagnosis of corneal abrasion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are consistent with corneal abrasion, which can be detected using fluorescein examination by observing the disrupted corneal epithelium under a cobalt blue light. Ocular ultrasonography, gonioscopy, and CT scan of the orbit are not useful in diagnosing corneal abrasion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has acute pain, discomfort, and tearing in the left eye after forgetting to remove his contact lenses. The immediate relief of pain after administration of a topical anesthetic indicates that the pain is likely due to corneal abrasion or ulcer, which can be visualized using fluorescein examination. Ocular ultrasonography, gonioscopy, and CT scan of the orbit are not indicated for this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In this case, the patient has a foreign body sensation and pain in the left eye. Administration of a topical anesthetic relieves the pain, suggesting it is related to the cornea. Fluorescein examination, which involves applying a special dye to the eye and examining it with blue light, can help establish the diagnosis of corneal abrasion or erosion. Ocular ultrasonography, gonioscopy, and CT scan of the orbit are not typically used to diagnose corneal injuries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of sleeping in contact lenses has caused immediate pain, discomfort, and tearing of the left eye, which suggests corneal abrasion. Fluorescein examination is the most common diagnostic test used for corneal abrasion, detecting corneal defects by staining the abrasion with a fluorescein dye. Ocular ultrasonography, gonioscopy, and CT scan are not necessary for the diagnosis of corneal abrasion.
